State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals Key Laboratory of Industrial Ecology and Environmental Engineering (MOE) School of Environmental Science and Technology Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China Graphical abstract A single semiconductor remains a great challenge for photocatalysis due to highly recombination of charge carriers. However, construction of multiple heterojunctions photocatalysts is an effective way for photocatalysis technique. Herein, two-dimensional sheet-like highly oriented SnS2/RGO/Ag (SRA) nanocomposites with multiple junctions including schottky- and RGO-n junctions designed and synthesized via hydrothermal strategy followed by in situ sequential UV reductions. The as-prepared SRA nanocomposites exhibited superior photoelectrochemical conversion efficiencies and photocatalytic activities for the degradation of typical antibiotics Norfloxacin (NOR) under simulated solar light condition, with the highest removal ratio of 94%. XPS and low temperature EPR technology demonstrates the existence of oxygen vacancies and chemical bond effect among SnS2, Ag and RGO components. Highly oriented crystal facet and efficient spatial charge carrier separations and interfacial transfers in the photo-induced redox reactions are evidenced by various physical techniques. Interestingly, in this paper, RGO was proposed to act as holes trapper to improve photo responsive charge separation in great extent. The mechanism of photoinduced redox reactions including the pathways of interfacial charges transfers and ROS species generations have been proposed in terms of the Density Functional Theory (DFT) quantum calculations and the outcomes of various physicochemical characterizations over SRA nanocomposites. Keywords SRA nanocomposites Multiple junctions Spatial charge carriers separation DFT quantum calculations 1 Introduction Antibiotics contamination is widespread found in environment, has drawn great environmental concerns [1–3]. Conventional techniques like biological, physical and chemical techniques have been applied for wastewater treatments [4]. Especially, photocatalysis has been considered a clean, economical technique method for decomposing environmental contaminants under mild condition [5–8]. With this background, high performance photocatalysts are viewed as one major factor for degradation of organic contaminants [9–11]. Metal sulfides with considerable ability absorbing light due to their narrow band gap [12]. They are considered efficient materials using as light-activated photocatalysts. For instance, CdS [13], In2S3 [14], CuInS2 [15] are reported for photocatalytic degradation. However, their applications are limited in degrading pollutants due to the environmental toxicity of Cd2+ and the scarcity of element Indium [16,17]. SnS2, an n-type semiconductor, is a CdI2-type structure layered compound, forms crystals two-dimensionally into hexagonal unit cells with Sn4+, Sn4+ ions are integrated to six chalcogenions in the octahedral sites with space group P3m1 [18–21]. In recent years, tin disulfide has attracted intensive application for Li-ion batteries, solar cells, sensors, especially as photocatalysts for pollutant degradation by virtue of its abundance, good stability and lower environmental toxicity [22–27]. However, SnS2 has low photocatalytic efficiency for the shortcomings of a high recombination rate of photoinduced charge carriers. Among the modification strategies explored, graphene oxide (GO) coupling with SnS2 through surface derivations and/or modifications could form RGO-n junctions to produce highly catalytic active nanocomposites with more efficient harvestings and absorptions towards simulated solar light [28–30]. RGO could interact with photocatalysts to enhance catalytic activity [31,32]. Recently, more greater efforts have been made to combine semiconductor with RGO (short for Reduced Graphene Oxide) to form RGO-based junctions for facilitating the separation of charge carriers [33]. For example, Wang et al. prepared preferred oriented TiO2-RGO nanocomposites by one step synthesis for easy-recycling and enhanced photocatalytic (PC) activity, and Zhang et al. researched photocatalytic activity of SnS2 by coupling with polyaniline and N-doped reduced graphene oxide [34,35]. RGO could facilitates charge carriers transferring, Y. Pu explored the interfacial charges kinetics of highly oriented Cu2O-RGO nano-heterostructures, and the RGO as electron relay constituent for mediating the interfacial charge transferring [36]. The novel physicochemical characteristics of the nanocomposites could be derived from the specific diverse structures, which are very beneficial for the enhancements of photo-generated charge carriers over the surface-interface in the nanocomposites. More recently, scientists realized that the nanocomposites with multiple junctions via rational design usually possess superior PEC and PC characteristics due to the spatial charge-carrier separations and interfacial transfers over light induced redox reactions. As reported by other researches, Metal doping and/or distribution of semiconductor could be excited by illumination, the charges on the semiconductor could inject into metal surface for high efficiency of charge carriers, such as Yuan et al. synthesized A novel SnS2-MgFe2O4/reduced graphene oxide flower-like photocatalyst, RGO is introduced to work as a high speed charge transfer channel to enhance the charge separation efficiency [37]. X. An synthesized 2-D Cu-SnS2/RGO nanocomposites, which would incur the sheet-on-sheet synergistic multiple-junctions followed by increasing surface adsorption and/or reaction active sites area for improving photoelectrochemical conversions and photocatalytic performance [38]. In this study, 2-D sheet-like highly oriented SnS2/RGO/Ag (SRA) nanocomposites with multiple junctions including schottky- and RGO-n junctions have been successfully designed and synthesized via hydrothermal strategy followed by in situ sequential UV reductions. The specific morphology and surface compositions of SRA have been systematically investigated and the simulated solar energy conversions and catalytic degradation of NOR of the SRA have also been carried out to check the PEC and PC behaviours, respectively. The as-prepared SRA nanocomposites exhibited superior photoelectrochemical conversion efficiencies and photocatalytic activities for the degradation of typical antibiotics Norfloxacin (NOR) under simulated solar light conditions, which are mainly attributed to their novel structural- and physico-chemical- characteristics including dual schottky- and RGO-n junctions, with the highest removal ratio of 94%. XPS and low temperature EPR technology demonstrates the existence of oxygen vacancies and chemical bond effect among SnS2, Ag and RGO components. Highly oriented crystal facet and highly efficient spatial charge carrier separations and interfacial transfers in the photo-induced redox reactions as evidenced by various physical techniques like fluorescent lifetime (FL), surface photovoltage technique (SPV) and UV–vis diffusion reflection spectra (DRS) etc. Interestingly, Enhanced PEC and PC activities has been clearly observed due to the spatial efficient separation and transfer of photogenerated electrons and holes. Additionally, the mechanism of photoinduced redox reactions including the pathways of interfacial charges transfers and ROS species generations has been proposed in terms of the Density Functional Theory (DFT) quantum calculations and the outcomes of various physicochemical characterizations over SRA nanocomposites. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Ag doped SnS2 nanosheet-RGO composite First, SR nanocomposites were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method. 0.175 g SnCl4·H2O, 0.3 g l-cysteinewere diffused in 30 ml DI water, stirred for 15 min, then 200 μl GO (4 mg/ml) solution was added and stirred the mixed solution for 3 h to reach a homogeneous solution. The mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and sustained at 180 °C for 24 h. The product was centrifuged, washed with water and ethanol several times, and then dried at 8 0°C in an vacuum oven for hours. Ag nanoparticles were in situ reduced to coat on SR nanocomposites by ultraviolet (UV) irradiation. Weighing SR compounds and a proportion of AgNO3 dissolved in deionized water and stirred for 3 h in the dark to form a homogeneous solution. Then adding appropriate amount of Ag, the mole ratio of SnS2 to Ag was calculated to be about 1, 3, 5. Next, the solution was stirred for 2 h under the UV irradiation of a 22 W low-pressure mercury lamp. Finally, the product was washed several times and then dried in a vacuum over for 6 h. 2.2 Photocatalytic activity tests The photocatalytic (PC) activity of SRA composites was assessed by removal of Norfloxacin (NOR) under sunlight irradiation conducted in a photochemical reactor. The reactor was filled with 100 ml NOR (initial concentration 20 mg/L), fixed quantity photocatalysts were suspended in the solution. All the experiments were conducted with magnetic stirring. Prior to irradiation, dark experiment was carried out magnetically for 2 h to assure the adsorption-desorption equilibrium. Then the solution was illuminated with a 500 W xenon lamp. The concentration of NOR was determined by using a UV-1100 spectrophotometer with the detective wavelength at 276 nm at regular intervals. 2.3 Computational details The electronic properties of RGO and Ag-modified SnS2 are investigated by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). Firstly, the geometry structures of SnS2 layer, RGO-SnS2 and RGO-SnS2-Ag are optimized before density of states (DOS) calculations. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was applied as the exchange-correlation function. The PAW pseudo-potential was used to describe the interaction between valence electrons and the ionic core. One 4 × 4 supercell with three S–Sn–S trilayers was used to simulate the SnS2 surface (Fig. 1 ). One RGO layer and one Ag cluster consisting of six atoms were placed on the two sides of SnS2 surface. Considering the balance between surpercell size and calculation cost, the geometry optimization was only performed at gamma point. The energy cutoff of plane-wave basis is set to 350 eV and the energy convergence to 1.0 × 10−4 eV. After geometry optimization, the Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh of 2 × 1 × 1 was adopted to conduct the calculations of PDOS. The other parameters were coincident to those of geometry optimization. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of photocatalysts SRA nanocomposites were fabricated by a facile hydrothermal reaction followed by sequential UV induced reductions. Metal-sulfide-RGO composites could be fabricated easily due to l-cysteine with to l-cysteine with more functional groups. The synthesized process is shown in Scheme 1 . Firstly, Sn4+ and ly-cysteine complex precursors are formed. Then, the precursors grow on the surface of the GO owing to the strong affinity between GO and l-cysteine. Upon the hydrothermal reactions, metal sulfide is formed and GO is reduced to RGO with the increased temperature and pressure [39]. Ag particles were doped on SR by reduction of AgNO3 under sequential UV irradiations. Finally, Ag NPs distribute on the SnS2 and RGO sheets. Fig. 2 a displayed the XRD patterns of SRA with different Ag content. The diffraction peaks of SnS2 at 2θ = 15.02°, 28.19°, 32.12°, 41.89°, 49.96°, 52.45°, 58.35° corresponding to the planes of (001), (100), (101), (102), (110), (111) and (200) can be indexed to Berndtite SnS2 (JCPDF card no. 23-0677) with lattice parameters of a = 3.649 Å, b = 3.649 Å and c = 5.899 Å. No RGO peaks were inspected might due to the less amount and low diffraction intensity, which might imply the coupling made no essential influence on the crystal structures of SnS2 [38]. However, the peak at 38°, which is in agreement with the (111) peak of Ag (JCPDS 04-0783) [40]. EDS analysis was conducted on the SRA nanocomposites. From the spectrum in Fig. 2b, Tin element peak appears at the position between 3.2 and 3.8 keV, the peak at about 2.4 keV corresponds to sulfur element. Carbon and oxygen element are also found in this pattern, which is considered to be from RGO. A small peak belonging to Ag arises, indicating the existence of Ag species due to AgNO3 reduction under UV sequential irradiations. The morphology and crystallinity of the SRA nanocomposites were then studied by SEM and TEM. From Fig. 3 a, the fabricated SnS2 and RGO present plate-shaped structure, and the SnS2 nanosheets assemble like a flower. Fig. 3b shows Ag particles coat on the SR sheets successfully. The TEM image in Fig. 3c–e further clearly display the nanosheets structure of SnS2, RGO and Ag particles. Moreover, SnS2 has well-layered structure, similar with graphene. The high magnification TEM image from Fig. 3f show SnS2 with a well–layered structure, and a close contact between SnS2 and RGO could be found. The interlayer distance of 0.59 nm corresponds to the highly oriented facet [001] plane of SnS2, similar with the previous reports [41]. Specifically, it could be clearly seen that Ag particles dispersed on the surface of SnS2 nanosheets and RGO sheets, respectively, and the lattice fringe of 0.24 nm can be assigned to Ag (111) plane [42,43]. Both the SEM and TEM results indicate the successful formation of SRA heterostructures. In order to investigate the chemical formations and states of the SRA nanocomposites, XPS was performed. The elements of Sn, S, C, O and Ag were observed. The two intensive peaks at 486.7 and 495.1 eV can be assigned to Sn 3d5/2 and Sn 3d3/2, respectively (Fig. 4 a). The energy difference between Sn 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 is 8.4 eV, indicative of the existence of Sn (IV) [38,44]. From Fig. 4b, the S 2p corresponds to an asymmetric peak, where the typical binding energy peaks of 161.9 and 163.2 eV are assigned to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2. While for SRA nanocomposites, the peak position of Sn 3d and S 2p shift to higher binding energies compared with pure SnS2, which implies that possible chemical bonding formation between SnS2, RGO and Ag components. The high resolution spectra of the Ag 3d is displayed in Fig. 4c. The peaks of Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 are at the position of 368 and 374 eV, with energy difference of 6 eV, attributing to the metallic silver [45,46]. The C 1s (284.8 eV) spectra can be segregated into three peaks corresponding to the presence of the sp2 bonded carbon CC (284.6 eV), the epoxy/hydroxyl groups CO (285.5 eV) and the carboxyl groups CO (287.7 eV), respectively (Fig. 4d) [47,48]. Compared with GO in Fig. S1, the peaks intensity of epoxy/hydroxyl groups and the carboxyl groups declined, which indicated that GO has been partial reduced. The presence of both SnS2 and RGO were further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectra of GO and SRA nanocomposites are exhibited in Fig. 5 . In the low frequency region, An visible peak at about 310 cm−1 was attributed to the A1g mode of SnS2 [49,50]. The Raman spectra of GO and RGO consist of two prominent characteristic peaks between 1300 cm−1 and 1700 cm−1, namely the D band and the G band. The G and D bands are identified with the vibration of the sp2 bonded carbon atoms in a two dimensional hexagonal lattice which is in agreement with an E2g mode of graphite, and the defects and disorder in the hexagonal graphitic layer which appears at ∼1350 cm−1, respectively [51–53]. Furthermore, the interactions between the RGO and SnS2 nanosheets are seen by the slight red shift in peaks of RGO from 1354 to 1350 cm−1 in the D band, 1560 to 1530 cm−1 in the G band. It is confirmed that the chemical interaction of these components with slight shifting in the bands [54]. The intensity ratio (ID/IG) of the D band to G band for GO is 0.97. Compared to GO, ID/IG for SRA nanocomposites increases to 1.40 as long as the existence of unrepaired defects after the elimination of partial oxygen moieties [55]. The increasing of ID/IG also suggests the interaction of SnS2, Ag into the RGO sheet. When the SRA nanocomposites were synthesized, SnS2, Ag interacts on the available defect sites of the RGO sheet. In pursuance of further demonstrating the chemical interaction and between SnS2, RGO and Ag components, we used a direct analysis method, namely low temperature EPR spectroscopy to prove the chemical binding of SnS2, RGO and Ag species. EPR technology can probe unpaired electron spins owing to the magnetic moments that absorb resonant microwave radiations in an externally applied magnetic field [56]. Fig. 6 shows the EPR absorption signals of SR and SRA samples. The two samples exhibit a remarkable EPR signal at g = 2, corresponding to the defects present in RGO. However, the signal intensity of SRA is lower than that of SR species, which can be explained by the formation of a chemical bond between SnS2, RGO and Ag, Ag occupied oxygen vacancies on RGO. SnS2, Ag are interacting with the unpaired electron spins of the RGO by the direct electron coupling of SnS2, Ag with the sp2 backbone of RGO. The adsorption range of light acts an important performance in PEC and PC activity. A comparison of DRS spectra for SnS2, SR, SRA with different content of Ag was investigated. As can be seen from Fig. 7 a, the absorption edge of SR nanocomposites is estimated to 610 nm, corresponding to band gap of ∼2.25 eV presented in Fig. 7b. After introducing Ag species, SRA nanocomposites show broader absorption in the visible light region compared to SR sample, the band gap is ∼1.65 eV, indicating their potential capabilities of utilizing visible light effectively, which may lead to a higher PEC and PC performance of the SRA nanocomposites. To provide more evidence on the photogenerated charge transfer occurring on the nanocomposite interface, the Photoluminescence lifetime spectroscopy of SRA nanocomposites was studied in comparison with that of SR. As displayed in Fig. 8 , in comparison with SR, the Photoluminescence lifetime for the SRA nanocomposites Ʈ1(1.3598 ns), Ʈ2 (3.7645 ns) are longer than the corresponding lifetime of SR with Ʈ1 (1.2473 ns), Ʈ2 (3.1606 ns). Obviously, SRA showed a longer lifetime. The FL decays obviously after doping Ag, indicating the photoinduced electrons and holes is suppressed by Ag. The prolonged lifetime stemmed from the formation of SRA schottky- and RGO-n junctions, which reduced the recombination of photoinduced electrons and holes [57]. The enhancement of PEC and PC activities might be most like due to the long-lived charge carriers [58].The formation of SRA multiple hetero-junctions including schottky junctions remarkably enhanced charge transfer efficiency, facilitated the PEC and PC reactions remarkably. It has been well recognized that the charge carriers separation plays an significant role in photoelectrochemical conversion and photoinduced catalytic processes. Herein, surface photovoltage (SPV) was conducted to study the behaviors of charge carriers. Fig. 9 displays the SPV spectra of SnS2, SR and SRA samples. In all cases, SPV signals show positive responses in the range of 300–500 nm, which demonstrates that band-to-band transition happens and photogenerated holes transfer to the surface. It is obviously seen that the photovoltaic response of SRA multiple junctions is higher than the other two samples. There exists stronger interaction between SnS2, RGO and Ag components, which would give rise to the more efficient separation of photogenerated charge carriers, resulting in a marvelous intensity enhancement of SPV signals. 3.2 Photoelectrochemical (PEC) measurement PEC measurements were performed to investigate the effect of SRA junctions on charge carriers separation and electron transfer process. From Fig. 10 a, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was shown in the manner of Nyquist diagram. It is known that a smaller radius of arc presents a lower charge carriers transfer resistance at electrode-electrolyte interface [16]. It is clear that SRA sample displays smaller charge transfer resistance than pure SnS2, The result reveals that the multiple junctions formation of SRA nanocomposites can decrease the photogenerated carriers transfer resistance, improving the photocatalytic activity. Moreover, the PEC photocurrent response of as-prepared materials with light on-off was carried out. As shown in Fig. 10b, the photocurrent response of SRA is higher than that of pure SnS2. Which means that SRA multiple junctions could improve the electron-hole pairs separation more effectively [58]. Mott–Schottky (M–S) plots were carried out to determine flat band potential of semiconductor. As shown in Fig. 11 , the positive slopes imply n-type qualities for SnS2 and SRA nanocomposites. Based on the intersection, the flat band potentials are −0.47 V and −0.31 V for SnS2, SRA versus the saturated calomel electrode (SCE), respectively. The smaller flat band position of SRA is considered to be due to the schottky- and RGO-n junctions structures. Ag, SnS2 and RGO components could lead to the positive shift of the flat band position, implying that the highly charge transfer arises at the surface of SRA nanocomposites. Moreover, the lower slop indicates a higher donor density, which could promote the transfer of electron-hole between these components 3.3 The photocatalytic activity of SRA for NOR degradation The photocatalytic activities of SR and SRA heterostructures were evaluated by testing the photodegradation and photocatalytic degradation of NOR, respectively. As shown from Fig. 12 , NOR is stable in the absence of photocatalysts, the NOR removal rate by photodegradation process is only 23%. However, the removal by photocatalytic degradation process with SRA-5 sample displays best performance, which might be attributed to higher charge transfer than other samples, facilitating photocatalytic reaction. It is clear that PC process yielded a better NOR removal rate because the light irradiation promotes the separation of photoinduced electron and hole effectively. Moreover, the reaction kinetics of NOR degradation was carried by a pseudo-first-order kinetic model (ln (C0 /C) = kt, t is the irradiation time and k is the rate constant). From Fig. S2, the kinetic constants of NOR degradation by NOR photodegradation, PC degradation with SR, SRA-1, SRA-3, SRA-5 are 1.72 × 10−3, 5.94 × 10−3, 8.14 × 10−3, 9.93 × 10−3, 1.46 × 10−2 min−1, respectively. The influence of different content of SRA-5 samples on degradation efficiency was conducted. From Fig. S3, the removal rate of 10 mg and 20 mg nanocomposites is better with the degradation efficiency of 94%. 3.4 The mechanism of photocatalytic NOR degradation 3.4.1 The electronic properties of SRA nanocomposites The electronic properties of SnS2, RGO-SnS2 and RGO-SnS2-Ag are investigated by density functional theory. The calculated results show that the introduction of RGO promotes the shift of Fermi level from the top of valence band to the bottom of conduction band (Fig. 13 a and b). This implies that the charge transfer in RGO-SnS2 layer is easier than that in bare SnS2. It is known that after light excitation of the nanocomposites, photo-induced charge carriers e.g., electrons and holes could be generated simultaneously. Obviously, since the partial 4d states of Ag is located in the bottom region of conduction band of SnS2 and the photo-generated electrons can easily transfer to the 4d states of Ag components to accomplish efficient charge separations. Meanwhile, the photo-generated holes possesses the availability of uptake the electrons in the C 2p states of RGO (e.g. acting as holes transporter) near the top region of valence band of SnS2 if sacrificial molecular (e.g., reactant molecular) were existed in the reactions. Obviously, the most efficient spatial charge-separation and interfacial transfers can be ultimately achieved owing to the dual-heterojunctions as derived from the SRA nanocomposites. Especially, the Ag and RGO layer tend to act as the reducing and oxidizing sites in the photocatalytic reaction, respectively. 3.4.2 The charge transfer mechanism of PC process with SRA In order to gain a deep insight into the photocatalytic mechanism, it is essential to identify the reactive radicals including reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the photoinduced catalytic reaction process.The main active radicals in the NOR degradation process were determined by the in situ experiments. As shown in Fig. 14 , the photocatalytic degradation of NOR was decelerated to some extent by the introduction of t-BuOH (hydroxyl radical scavenger) and p-benzoquinone (O2 −scavenger), implying that O2 − and OH were the major active oxidizing species responsible for NOR degradation. After introducing 1 mM EDTA (h+ scavenger), the NOR degradation was also suppressed for a certain extent, which indicated that h+ was involved in the NOR degradations. Based on the above analysis, the CB and VB potential of SnS2 are about −0.25 eV and 2 eV, respectively. The suggested photocatalytic mechanism is displayed in Scheme 2 , under the light irradiations, electrons are excited to the CB from the VB of SnS2, the electron-hole pairs are generated simultaneously. It is learnt from previously reports that bunch of the photo-generated electrons and holes could recombine quickly, and the photocatalytic activity of SnS2 is substantially depressed due to less photoinduced charge carries participate in the photo-induced catalytic process. However, when SnS2 is combined with RGO and Ag, both of schottky- and RGO-n junctions formations would facilitate the tailored charge carrier behavior, i.e, the holes on the VB of SnS2 could transfer towards the surface of RGO sheets quickly, promoting the spatial separation and interfacial transfer of the photoinduced electrons and holes. It has been reported that the 2-D large π-conjugation structure of RGO provides abundance of delocalized electrons to enhance the transport of charge carriers [59,60]. At the same time, owing to the schottky junction formed, the photoinduced electrons of SnS2 could transfer to Ag species. As a result, the separation efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers is effectively promoted at the interface of the multiple junctions. The photo-induced electrons on Ag species can be scavenged by molecular oxygen in the aqueous water, resulting in ROS species including O2 − radicals, which are the predominant active species in the catalytic reaction with NOR [40]. Meanwhile, the VB of SnS2 is over 1.99 eV(OH−/OH), implying that holes transferring to RGO surface from VB of SnS2 could generate OH radicals by reacting with H2O to participate in degrading NOR. During the photocatalytic process, the reactive species OH, O2 − formed on SRA multiple heterojunctions by the electrons and holes reacting with the surface chemisorbed O2, H2O, have a strong oxidative capacity and play vital role in degradation of antibiotics NOR contaminated species. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the 2D sheet-like highly oriented SRA nanocomposites with dual schottky- and RGO-n junctions have been synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method and in-situ deposition of Ag nanoparticles under sequential UV irradiations. The as-prepared SRA nanocomposites display high photoelectrochemical conversion and photoinduced catalytic activity for NOR degradation under simulated solar light conditions. The synergistic interaction among SnS2, RGO and Ag components contributes to the transport of charge carriers to the surface of Ag and RGO greatly, which could improve the separation of electrons and holes efficiently and extend the lifetime of the charge carriers simultaneously. More importantly, the mechanism for enhanced PEC and PC performance has been illustrated based on joint photo-electrochemical properties and DFT theory. Furthermore, reactive species (OH, O2 −) were predominate active species in the photoinduced catalytic degradation of toxic species process. The maximum degradation efficiency of NOR over SRA nanocomposites is 94%. Therefore, the SRA nanocomposites with multiple junctions could serve as a prospective functional materials both for solar light utilisation and conversion as well as environmental eliminations in terms of fundamental and applied research. coredata.dc:description: A single semiconductor remains a great challenge for photocatalysis due to highly recombination of charge carriers. However, construction of multiple heterojunctions photocatalysts is an effective way for photocatalysis technique. Herein, two-dimensional sheet-like highly oriented SnS2/RGO/Ag (SRA) nanocomposites with multiple junctions including schottky- and RGO-n junctions designed and synthesized via hydrothermal strategy followed by in situ sequential UV reductions. The as-prepared SRA nanocomposites exhibited superior photoelectrochemical conversion efficiencies and photocatalytic activities for the degradation of typical antibiotics Norfloxacin (NOR) under simulated solar light condition, with the highest removal ratio of 94%. XPS and low temperature EPR technology demonstrates the existence of oxygen vacancies and chemical bond effect among SnS2, Ag and RGO components. Highly oriented crystal facet and efficient spatial charge carrier separations and interfacial transfers in the photo-induced redox reactions are evidenced by various physical techniques. Interestingly, in this paper, RGO was proposed to act as holes trapper to improve photo responsive charge separation in great extent. The mechanism of photoinduced redox reactions including the pathways of interfacial charges transfers and ROS species generations have been proposed in terms of the Density Functional Theory (DFT) quantum calculations and the outcomes of various physicochemical characterizations over SRA nanocomposites.
coredata.dc:title: Highly oriented SnS2/RGO/Ag heterostructures for boosting photoeletrochemical and photocatalytic performances via schottky and RGO-n dual-heterojunctions interfacial effects
